week3.practice1_html:
```html

Toby, your shedding is still worsening just ~2 months after COVID and over-training—classic early “onset → peak” window. Right now your sleep is under 5h, meals low in protein, and your body is under repair stress. A solid, protein-rich breakfast is the big domino: it calms morning cortisol, anchors circadian rhythm after rough nights, and feeds follicles with the amino acids they need so stabilization can arrive sooner and regrowth isn’t delayed. 🌱

What to do

  • Eat within 60–90 min of waking
  • Include at least 25–30 g of protein (keeps cortisol steadier)
  • Add colorful plants (antioxidants buffer post-illness inflammation)
  • Keep it simple & fast so you don’t skip on busy mornings

Your plan

  • Omnivore quickie: 2 eggs + Greek yogurt cup + berries
  • Vegan quickie: Protein smoothie (soy/pea protein, banana, spinach, flax)
  • Batch-prep overnight oats with protein powder to remove decision fatigue
  • Pair with glass of water + 5 min light exposure by a window to anchor circadian rhythm

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Set your alarm 15 min earlier so breakfast isn’t rushed after nights of broken sleep.
  2. Pre-pack smoothie ingredients in freezer bags so your half-awake self just blends.
  3. Use your phone timer to remind you to actually eat vs. doom-scroll past the window.
  4. Limit caffeine until after breakfast (push that “after 3 pm” habit earlier too).
  5. Follow meal with a few deep breaths or stretch—signals safety to your nervous system.

Why this works (for you)

  • Protein-rich mornings flatten the big cortisol swings worsened by <5h sleep, reducing telogen push.
  • Because your illness was in Sept, shedding may peak into Nov; feeding follicles daily shortens time-to-stabilization and nudges regrowth into its usual 3–4 mo window.
  • Early balanced fuel steadies mood/anxiety, lowering the doom-scroll stress loop that fragments your nights.
  • Iron and amino acids in these options build hemoglobin and keratin substrates critical for regrowth once shedding stabilizes.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: Skipping breakfast or loading pastries only → likely more fatigue, unstable blood sugar, extended shedding curve.
  • Green lights: Within 7–10 days, steadier mid-morning energy; less jittery caffeine need; fewer doom-scroll spirals before bed.
  • You don’t need perfection—just show up most mornings. Every protein start is a tiny vote for regrowth ❤️
```
week3.practice2_html:
Toby, your body is still in the peak shedding phase—hair loss is worsening from the July over-exercise and September illness. Low protein intake, spotty nutrition, and late meals before short nights are keeping your system from moving into stabilization. The “plate tweak” is your big domino here: giving your follicles the raw materials (protein, iron, omega‑3s) to shorten the lag and set up regrowth once shedding slows. 🌱

What to do

  • Aim for protein at all 3 meals (20–30 g each)
  • Add omega‑3 source 2–3x/week (salmon, sardines, chia, or flax)
  • Build iron‑rich plates with beans, spinach, lentils, lean meats
  • Pair plants + vitamin C (peppers, citrus) to absorb iron better
  • Shift your last meal a bit earlier (2–3 hrs before bed) for deeper sleep

Your plan

  • Breakfast (anchor): Greek yogurt parfait with berries + chia
  • Lunch: Lentil & spinach soup + slice of whole‑grain toast
  • Dinner: Grilled salmon, quinoa, roasted broccoli
  • If late hunger hits: small protein snack (boiled egg, edamame) instead of a full meal

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Start tomorrow with a protein‑forward breakfast (≥25 g).
  2. Batch cook 1–2 iron/omega‑3 rich meals on Sunday to reduce weeknight friction.
  3. Keep vitamin C fruit/veg handy—add them wherever you eat beans/greens.
  4. Set a “last bite” cutoff ~2 hrs before intended sleep; prep a lighter snack option if needed.
  5. If late caffeine cravings strike, sub green tea (earlier) or herbal tea (after 3 pm).

Why this works (for you)

  • Because sleep is <5 hrs/night, deeper nutrition helps blunt cortisol and preserves protein stores that hair needs while your sleep stabilizes.
  • Your peak shedding (~Sep–Oct) reflects lag from July + illness. Adequate protein/iron shortens time‑to‑stabilization so regrowth can begin on schedule.
  • Irregular periods suggest possible iron risk—even without heavy flow. This plan cushions that gap safely with food.
  • Earlier meals = steadier night melatonin → more repair signals to roots.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: skipping meals or relying on coffee as breakfast → intensifies shedding pressure; gently reset the next meal to include protein.
  • Green lights: within ~10–14 days, you notice (1) less intense handfuls in shower, (2) energy more stable through the day, (3) fewer night wakings after earlier dinners.
  • Progress may feel slow, but each balanced plate is a vote toward regrowth. You’re building the floor your follicles need. ❤️
week3.practice3_html:
Toby, your shedding is still in the worsening phase because the fever illness is ongoing and sleep is so short (<5h). Right now your body is in "cortisol survival mode." Adding the right fats is a big domino—EPA/DHA-rich omega‑3s calm inflammation from illness stress and give your follicles raw material to re‑enter growth once stability lands. Think of this as priming the soil while your body fights through the storm 🌱.

What to do

  • Aim for 2–3 portions of fatty fish (salmon, sardines, mackerel) per week—or algae oil if plant‑based.
  • If supplementing, choose triglyceride‑form, refrigerated fish oil; avoid capsules that smell "fishy" (sign of rancidity).
  • Balance: look for combined EPA + DHA, at least 500–1000 mg total per day.
  • Cut back on processed seed oils (corn, soybean, sunflower)—they tilt inflammation the wrong way.

Your plan

  • Anchor omega‑3 foods at least 3x in the week ahead.
  • Pair with protein (important since you usually only hit 1 high‑protein meal/day).
  • Keep fats earlier than 1h before bed to ease digestion with your late dinners.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Write down three meals this week where you can swap in salmon, tuna, or sardines instead of chicken/noodles.
  2. If that feels too heavy, add 1–2 tsp ground flax or chia to breakfast until fish feels doable.
  3. Buy small packs of frozen fish; keeps fresher if you're only eating 1–2 portions a week.
  4. Take supplements with the first meal of the day, not at night (helps stomach, avoids reflux at bedtime).
  5. When doom‑scrolling urges pop up at night, prep tomorrow’s protein+fat meal instead—small shift, big ripple ❤️.

Why this works (for you)

  • Omega‑3s dampen fever/illness‑driven inflammation → fewer follicles pushed into rest, helping shed stabilize faster.
  • Because your over‑exercise trigger has resolved, nutrition now distinguishes whether you enter stabilization by month 3–4 or stay shedding longer.
  • Pairing fats with protein covers two weak spots (you’re low on both) → fuels regrowth signals once shedding levels out.
  • Late meals + short sleep keep cortisol high; eating clean fats earlier in the evening softens that curve.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: Fish oil burps, nausea, or very loose stools → reduce dose, split into 2 smaller servings.
  • Green lights: Within 1–2 weeks: smoother skin, less hair static/frizz, digestion calmer after rich meals.
  • Remember, your shedding may not stop instantly—but these fats are laying down brickwork for the regrowth start phase that’s waiting on stability. Stay the course ✨.
